metadata.title: Form factors for B → j 1 j 2 decays into two currents in QCD

location.addrLine: Roma Tre, Via della Vasca Navalle

abstract.text: We discuss the general properties of the B-meson decay form factors F (q 2 , q ′2 ), describing Bmeson decays induced by two currents, e.g., B-decays into four leptons in the final state. We study the analytic properties of these complicated objects and identify those regions of q 2 and q ′2 , where perturbative QCD can be applied for obtaining predictions for the physical form factors.

body_text.text: The goal of this paper is to study the general properties of the B-meson form factors into two currents. Such quantities emerge, e.g., in the B-meson decays into four leptons in the final state; the latter reactions are being studied experimentally [1] [2] [3] [4] , thus requiring a proper theoretical understanding of the B-meson form factors into two currents. By now, there have been only few papers [5, 6] , where B-decays into two lepton pairs have been studied theoretically, using a rather naive model for the B-decay form factors. To obtain reliable predictions for four-lepton B-decays one needs a detailed understanding of the appropriate form factors in the timelike region. In particular, one needs to study the analytic properties of the latter in broad ranges of momentum transfers, including the timelike regions of four-lepton decays, in order to understand where model-independent predictions for such form factors directly from QCD may be obtained. The knowledge of rigorous properties of such form factors from field theory allows one to obtain constraints to be used in building realistic phenomenological models for the amplitudes of various four-lepton decays.

In the past, theoretical analyses focused on a family of similar reactions, namely, the B → γl + l − and B → γlν decays (see, e.g., [7] [8] [9] [10] [11] ); these processes are described by the same form factors as four-lepton B-decays, but evaluated for a zero value of one of the momenta squared. The corresponding form factors depend on one variable q 2 , q being the momentum of the weak current. Various versions of light-cone QCD sum rules [12] [13] [14] [15] [16] [17] [18] have been applied to obtain the theoretical predictions for such processes. The B-decays into two currents are related to correlation functions containing B-meson in the initial state and one can calculate them in QCD via the B-meson distribution amplitudes [19] [20] [21] [22] .
The form factors of our interest are complicated objects defined by the following amplitude T (q, q ′ |p) = i dx e iqx 0|T {s(x)Ob(x), j(0)}|B(p) = F (q 2 , q ′2 ), p = q + q ′ .
In practically interesting cases, the weak currents(x)Ob(x) contains some Dirac matrix O, and j(y) may be the electromagnetic current j e.m.

Respectively, the amplitude (1.1) involves a number of Lorentz structures and form factors F i (q 2 , q ′2 ); each of these form factors receives contributions from two diagrams shown in Fig. 1 . The diagram Fig. 1(a) gives the dominant contribution in the heavy-quark limit [8, 9] and we shall therefore discuss this diagram. For the sake of argument, we omit here the Lorentz and the spinor indices and consider field theory with scalar partciles. Such an approach allows us to avoid techncal complications and to concentrate on the conceptual aspects [23] [24] [25] . Still, we keep the QCD notations of the quark fields b and s and denoteb ands the complex conjugate fields. Here b denotes the b-quark field and s denotes the light-quark field (d, u or s). We have used the Feynman quark propagator for the calculation of the hadron form factor. This procedure is consistent if the bulk of the form factor comes from the integration region where quark is far from it mass shell. Taking into account the peaking of φ(ξ) near ξ ∼ Λ QCD /m b , we find that the propagating light quark is highly virtual, k 2 ∼ −Λ QCD m b , in the region of the external momenta satisfying q 2 < M 2 B and q ′2 < Λ QCD m b . In this region, the propagator is positive and large in the ξ-integration region and our calculation of the B-meson form factor is trustable. 1 Another region of the external momenta where Eq. (3.10) gives trustable predictions for the B-meson form factor corresponds to those q 2 and q ′2 where the denominator in (3.10) is negative and large in the full ξ-integration region and thus the light s-quark is far from its mass shell.

Let us turn to those contributions to the form factor that are generated by higher twist effects (i.e. higher powers of x 2 ) in the expansion (2.4) . To calculate such contributions, it is convenient to substitute in Eq. (3.8) x α = −i ∂ ∂kα e ikx . By performing the parts integration, the k α -derivative acts on the s-quark propagator. Therefore in the region where the quark propagator is highly virtual, k 2 ∼ −Λ QCD m b , the contributions of higher-twist terms are power-suppressed (x 2 ) n → (Λ QCD /m b ) n compared to leading-twist LC term.

The analytic properties of the form factor (1.3) depend on the singularities of the denominator in the integral (1.3). Therefore, the structure of singularities is the same in the LC and in the higher-twist contributions, and we will concentrate on the analytic properties of the LC form factor (3.10).
Before studing these properties, however, we discuss some model-independent predictions for the behaviour of the form factor in specific regions of q 2 and q ′2 .

In some regions of the momentum transfers q 2 and q ′2 , model-independent features of the form factor F (q 2 , q ′2 ) may be established. To highlight these properties, one needs to make use of only one essential property of the LC wave function φ(ξ): namely, its peaking in the end-point region ξ ≃ Λ QCD /m b . This peaking reflects the fact that the major part of the heavy-meson momentum is carried by the heavy quark.

body_text.text: We now turn to the analysis of the analytic properties of the form factor (3.10). Because of the Feynman propagator in the integrand, this ξ-integral is a contour integral in the complex ξ-plane along the cut located at 0 < ξ < 1. Consequently, the analytic properties of the form factor are determined by the motion of the singularities of the denominator in the complex ξ-plane depending on q 2 and q ′2 , and the analytic properties of the form factor in the theory with scalar "quarks" coincide with the analytic properties of the form factor in QCD.

Clearly, if q 2 < m 2 and q ′2 < m 2 , the denominator is positive in the ξ-integration region; the −i0 addition may be safely omitted, and the form factor is the real function in this kinematic domain. However, if one of the variables, q 2 or q ′2 , lies in the timelike region above m 2 , the form factor acquires the imaginary part. As we shall see, F (q 2 , q ′2 ) has logarithmic branch points in this kinematical region and the analysis of its analytic properties becomes a more complicated problem. To get to the right branch of the logarithmic cut, it is convenient to keep a small imaginary addition in m, the mass of the propagating particle, i.e. to replace m 2 → m 2 − i0.

This happens for q 2 > q 2 c , where q 2 c = M 2 B + q ′2 − 2MB q ′2 − m 2 . For q 2 > q 2 c , ξ+ and ξ− are complex conjugate numbers, ξ+ = ξ * − . Since q 2 c < (MB − q ′2 ) 2 , q 2 c lies beyond the physical region of the B-decay.

In this Section, we address two problems: First, we illustrate the general structure of the form factor by the calculation in an explicit model for the LC DA (2.6) with n = 9; Second, we demonstrate the sensitivity of the form factor to the specific shape of the LC DA, comparing the results obtained with two different LC DAs. For numerical estimates we need input parameters such as "quark" masses and the DA of "B-meson" in our model with scalar constituents. We will make use of the realistic values of quark and meson masses m s = 0.1 GeV, m b = 4.2 GeV, and M B = 5.27 GeV. Throughout this Section, we normalize the LC DA as 1 0 φ(ξ)dξ = 1.

A. Form factor in a broad range of momentum transfers Figure 3 shows the form factor as function of two variables q 2 and q ′2 in a broad range of momentum transfers for the B-meson LC DA (2.6) with n = 9; the form factor in this case may be obtained as an explicit function containing polynomials and logarithms. The physical B-decay region is restricted to timelike q and q ′ such that q 2 + q ′2 ≤ M B ; it corresponds to a part of the region displayed in the plot. The physical region of the B-decay is narrower and is determined by the following conditions: 4m 2 l < q 2 , 4m 2 l < q ′2 , and q 2 + q ′2 ≤ MB. Recall that the Feynman rules prescribe a small imaginary addition −iǫ in the propagator, so, more rigorously, we have the function of three variables, F (q 2 , q ′2 |ǫ). The form factor is then defined as F (q 2 , q ′2 ) ≡ F (q 2 , q ′2 |ǫ → 0). The limit ǫ → 0 may be taken without problem for all momentum transfers, except for the family of "critical" points q 2 and q ′2 for which both roots ξ + and ξ − pinch in the limit ǫ → 0, i.e., those q 2 and q ′2 which satisfy the condition 4M 2 B m 2 + (M 2 B − q ′2 + q 2 ) 2 − 4M 2 B q 2 = 0. This condition determines a "critical" curve (a parabola) in the q 2 -q ′2 -plane, where the function F (q 2 , q ′2 |ǫ) has an essentail singularity and the limiting values lim ǫ→0 F (q 2 c , q ′2 |ǫ) and lim q 2 →q 2 c F (q 2 , q ′2 |ǫ = 0) differ from each other. B. Sensitivity of the form factor to the DA shape As seen from the results of Section 4, in some regions of the momentum transfers the form factor is expected to be sensitive to the DA shape, in particular, to the value of its first inverse moment ξ −1 = 1 0 φ(ξ) ξ dξ. We study the sensitivity of the form factor to the specific shape of the DA for three cases

The DA (6.20) was proposed in [19] in the context of heavy-quark effective theory. We use this parametrization for comparison although it does not strictly vanish at ξ = 1. Fig. 5 compares the result corresponding to DA (6.19) for n = 9 and to (6.20) ; for the latter, we fix the parameter β B such that ξ −1 for both parametrizations are equal to each other, ξ −1 = 11; this requirement yields β = 0.38 GeV. Obviously, for a fixed value of ξ −1 , the form factor is weakly sensitive to the precise shape of the B-meson DA: the sensitivity does not exceed a level of a few percent, at least in the region where our calculation of the form factors may be directly applied to the data. A similar picture is seen for other values of q 2 and q ′2 . Fig. 6 illustrates the sensitivity of the form factor to the value of ξ −1 of the corresponding B-meson DA φ(ξ): we compare the form factor evaluated with DAs of (6.19) for n = 9 ( ξ −1 = 11) and for n = 11 ( ξ −1 = 13). Indeed, as could be expected from the results of Section 4, there are regions of q 2 and q ′2 , where the sensitivity to the value of ξ −1 of the B-meson DA is strong.

We presented the analysis of the analytic properties of the form factor F (q 2 , q ′2 ) which describes the B-decay into two currents. A practically interesting application of this object is the decay of B-meson into four leptons.

The results obtained above are based on the integral representation for the form factor F (q 2 , q ′2 ) in terms of the B-meson field-theoretic wave function and the quark propagator, for which the Feynman form is used. One knows, however, that the QCD confinement distorts this propagator in the soft region of momentum transfers: the Feynman propagator provides a good approximation to the full quark propagator in the region where the quark is highly virtual; in the problem under consideration it is sufficient that the quark virtuality is of order Λ QCD m b . In practice, when one calculates the ξ-integral for the form factor in the B-decay kinematics, i.e. for q 2 + q ′2 ≤ M B , one always picks up a contribution from the integration region where the quark propagator is not sufficiently hard. This is however not a great problem as soon as the major part of the form factor comes from the integration region where the quark is highly virtual. The region where the quark is soft leads to the appearance of the imaginary part of the form factor. We therefore conclude that the results for the decay form factor obtained by calculating the correlation function (1.3) with Feynman quark and gluon propagators may be directly applied to the analysis of the realistic B-decay in those regions of q 2 and q ′2 where the imaginary part of the calculated form factor is much smaller than its real part. This criterion may be used as a guiding principle for verifying the theoretical predictions for the form factors of interest and for restricting phenmenological parametrizations.

We studied the sensitivity of the form factor F (q 2 , q ′2 ) to the B-meson DA. It was found that the form factor is weakly sensitive to the precise shape of the B-meson DA, provided its first inverse moment ξ −1 is fixed. On the other hand, there are regions of q 2 and q ′2 , where the form factor exhibits a sizeable sensitivity to the precise value of ξ −1 of the B-meson DA.

Obviously, for obtaining the predictions for form factor of B-decays in QCD one should include quark spins into the game. Neverhteless, the presented analysis of the analytic properties of the form factors and the predictions for the behaviour of the form factor in the specific regions of q 2 and q ′2 are quite general and hold also in the real QCD.
Some of these predictions are listed below:
(i) In the region q ′2 = q 2 , and |q 2 | ≫ M B Λ QCD , the leading behaviour of the form factor reads F (q 2 , q 2 ) = f B −q 2 . (7.21)

(ii) For q ′2 ≃ Λ 2 QCD , the form factor in a broad range of q 2 has a monopole behaviour F (q 2 , q ′2 ≃ Λ 2 QCD ) = 1 (M 2 B − q 2 ) 1 0 dξ φ(ξ) ξ . (7.22) (iii) In the region M B Λ QCD ≤ q ′2 ≤ M 2 B and for all 0 < q 2 < M 2 B , the form factor has the form

The study presented here is just the first step in the analysis of complicated amplitudes of B-decays into two currents. We believe however that this is a useful step as it describes the general analytic properties of F (q 2 , q ′2 ) in quantum field theory, valid also for form factors in QCD.
